verses.text: Joab, son of Zeruiah, realized that the king’s heart longed for Absalom.
verses.comment: Reflects Joab’s recognition of David's feelings; language updated for clarity.

verses.text: So Joab sent to Tekoa and brought from there a wise woman. He said to her, “Pretend to be in mourning and wear mourning clothes. Do not anoint yourself with oil, but act like a woman who has been mourning for the dead a long time.”
verses.comment: Modernized speech; keeps the instruction from Joab.

verses.text: Joab continued, “Go to the king and speak to him in this way.” Then Joab put the words in her mouth.
verses.comment: Clarifies Joab's coaching of the woman’s speech.

verses.text: When the woman from Tekoa spoke to the king, she fell down with her face to the ground and bowed before him, saying, “Help, O king!”
verses.comment: Matches the original request for help.

verses.text: The king asked her, “What is wrong?” She answered, “I am indeed a widow; my husband is dead.”
verses.comment: Direct speech, modernized.

verses.text: Your servant had two sons. They were fighting with each other in the field, and there was no one to separate them. One struck the other and killed him.
verses.comment: Reflects the woman’s parable; clear wording.

verses.text: Now the whole clan has risen against your servant, saying, ‘Give up the murderer of his brother, so we may kill him for taking his brother’s life and destroy the heir as well.’ In this way they will extinguish what is left to me, leaving my husband neither name nor descendant on earth.”
verses.comment: Slightly condensed for readability; keeps core meaning.

verses.text: The king said to the woman, “Go to your house, and I will issue orders concerning you.”
verses.comment: Aligns with King David's response.

verses.text: The woman of Tekoa said to the king, “My lord the king, let the guilt fall on me and my father's house; the king and his throne are guiltless.”
verses.comment: Clarifies her request to bear the blame.

verses.text: The king replied, “If anyone speaks against you, bring him to me, and he will not trouble you again.”
verses.comment: Simplifies David's assurance.

verses.text: Then she said, “Please, let the king remember the LORD your God, so the avenger of blood does not destroy anymore, or they will destroy my son.” He answered, “As the LORD lives, not a hair of your son’s head will fall to the ground.”
verses.comment: Uses phrase familiar from other scripture; preserves oath language.

verses.text: Then the woman said, “Please, let your servant speak a word to my lord the king.” He said, “Speak.”
verses.comment: Recognizes royal permission to speak.

verses.text: The woman said, “Why then have you planned this thing against the people of God? For by speaking this word, the king is like someone guilty, since he does not bring back his banished son.”
verses.comment: Direct challenge to David; slightly expanded for clarity.

verses.text: We must all die, and are like water spilled on the ground which cannot be gathered up again. But God does not take away life; he plans ways so that the banished may not remain banished from him.
verses.comment: Keeps metaphor for death and restoration.

verses.text: Now I have come to say this to my lord the king because the people made me afraid. So your servant said, ‘Let me speak to the king; maybe he will grant my request.’
verses.comment: Expresses her motivation clearly.

verses.text: For the king will listen and rescue his servant from the hand of the man who would destroy me and my son from the inheritance God gave us.”
verses.comment: Adds context about inheritance.

verses.text: Your servant thought, ‘May the word of my lord the king give me rest.’ For my lord the king is like an angel of God in discerning good and evil. May the LORD your God be with you!”
verses.comment: ‘Angel of God’ phrase retained from original.

verses.text: Then the king answered the woman, “Do not hide anything I ask you.” The woman said, “Let my lord the king speak.”
verses.comment: Keeps direct dialogue.

verses.text: The king asked, “Is the hand of Joab with you in all this?” The woman answered, “As you live, my lord the king, no one can turn to the right or left from anything you have said. It was indeed your servant Joab who told me, and he put all these words in your servant’s mouth.
verses.comment: Reveals Joab's involvement; oath phrase updated to clarify.

verses.text: Joab did this to give the situation a different appearance. But my lord is wise, with the wisdom of an angel of God, knowing all that happens in the land.”
verses.comment: Acknowledges David's wisdom as the original does.

verses.text: Then the king said to Joab, “All right, I will do this. Go, bring back the young man Absalom.”
verses.comment: Updates speech for modern clarity.

verses.text: Joab fell with his face to the ground and bowed, and blessed the king. Then Joab said, “Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your sight, my lord the king, because the king has granted the request of his servant.”
verses.comment: Reflects Joab's gratitude and humility.

verses.text: So Joab went to Geshur and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Absalom’s location and return stated clearly.

verses.text: But the king said, “He must go to his own house; he is not to see my face.” So Absalom went to his own house and did not see the king’s face.
verses.comment: King David’s conditions for Absalom’s return.

verses.text: Now in all Israel there was no one praised as highly as Absalom for his appearance. From the sole of his foot to the top of his head, there was no blemish on him.
verses.comment: Focuses on Absalom’s physical perfection.

verses.text: When he cut the hair of his head, every year at the end of the year, because it became too heavy for him, he would cut it. He weighed the hair of his head, and it was two hundred shekels by the king’s weight.
verses.comment: Historical weight retained; modern equivalents not inserted.

verses.text: To Absalom were born three sons and one daughter, whose name was Tamar. She was a beautiful woman.
verses.comment: Mentions Absalom's daughter Tamar, same as his sister.

verses.text: Absalom lived two full years in Jerusalem without seeing the king’s face.
verses.comment: Time passed emphasized; matches original.

verses.text: Absalom sent for Joab to send him to the king, but Joab would not come to him. He sent a second time, but Joab still would not come.
verses.comment: Reflects Absalom’s repeated requests and Joab’s refusal.

verses.text: So Absalom said to his servants, “See, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go, set it on fire.” So Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.
verses.comment: Absalom’s method to get Joab's attention.

verses.text: Then Joab came to Absalom at his house and said, “Why did your servants set my field on fire?”
verses.comment: Joab confronts Absalom; direct speech.

verses.text: Absalom answered Joab, “I sent to you, saying, ‘Come here so I can send you to the king to ask, “Why have I come from Geshur? It would have been better for me to be there.” Now, let me see the king’s face, and if I am guilty of anything, let him put me to death.’”
verses.comment: Preserves Absalom’s challenge, worded for clarity.

verses.text: So Joab went to the king and told him. Then David summoned Absalom, and he came to the king and bowed down his face to the ground before him. The king kissed Absalom.
verses.comment: Summarizes reconciliation clearly and faithfully.
